questions.question: Which virtue is most highlighted in the story?

questions.question: What is the title of the story?
questions.answer: The Happy Prince.

questions.question: Who is the author of 'The Happy Prince'?
questions.answer: Oscar Wilde.

questions.question: What was the statue of the Happy Prince covered with?
questions.answer: Gold.

questions.question: What were the Happy Prince's eyes made of?
questions.answer: Bright blue jewels.

questions.question: What hung from the statue's waist?
questions.answer: A red jewel.

questions.question: Why did people admire the statue?
questions.answer: Because it was very beautiful and they thought it represented happiness.

questions.question: Who landed between the feet of the Happy Prince?
questions.answer: A little Swallow.

questions.question: What fell on the Swallow?
questions.answer: Tears from the Happy Prince's eyes.

questions.question: Why was the Happy Prince crying?
questions.answer: Because he could see all the unhappiness of his city and his heart could feel sorrow.

questions.question: What did the Happy Prince not know when he was alive?
questions.answer: He did not know what tears or sadness were.

questions.question: Where did the Happy Prince live when he was alive?
questions.answer: In a palace with a walled garden, isolated from suffering.

questions.question: What was the first gift from the Happy Prince?
questions.answer: The red jewel from his waist.

questions.question: Who received the red jewel?
questions.answer: A poor woman with an ill son.

questions.question: Why was the mother forced to ignore her ailing son?
questions.answer: She was busy making a dress for a queen's lady to earn money.

questions.question: Why did the Swallow feel warm after delivering the jewel?
questions.answer: Because he had done a good deed.

questions.question: What surprised the clever man?
questions.answer: Seeing a swallow in winter, which was unusual.

questions.question: Who received the first blue jewel (the Prince's eye)?
questions.answer: A young, poor writer.

questions.question: Why was the writer unable to complete his story?
questions.answer: He was very cold, weak, and hungry; there was no fire in his room.

questions.question: What did the writer conclude when he saw the blue jewel?
questions.answer: That someone liked his stories and it was a gift from a reader.

questions.question: Who received the second blue jewel?
questions.answer: A little girl selling eggs in the square.

questions.question: Why did the Swallow refuse to take the Prince's other eye initially?
questions.answer: Because then the Prince would not be able to see.

questions.question: Why did the Swallow wish to go to Egypt?
questions.answer: Because it was warm and green there, unlike the cold winter where he was.

questions.question: What did the Swallow discover and report to the Happy Prince?
questions.answer: He saw poor people, hungry children with sad eyes, and boys trying to keep warm under a bridge.

questions.question: What did the Happy Prince ask the Swallow to do with his gold covering?
questions.answer: To take it off piece by piece and give it to the poor people.

questions.question: What happened to the Happy Prince's appearance after the gold was removed?
questions.answer: He looked grey and ugly.

questions.question: What happened to the little Swallow in the end?
questions.answer: He died from the cold at the feet of the Happy Prince.

questions.question: What sound was heard inside the statue after the Swallow died?
questions.answer: A crack - the metal heart broke into two pieces.

questions.question: What did the important man in the city say about the statue?
questions.answer: He said it did not look bright; the jewel was gone, eyes missing, and it looked like a beggar.

questions.question: What part of the statue did not melt in the fire?
questions.answer: The broken heart (the metal heart).

questions.question: What did God's servants bring to Him?
questions.answer: The broken heart and the dead bird.

questions.question: Why did God say they brought the right things?
questions.answer: Because the Swallow's sacrifice and the Prince's loving heart were the two best things in the city.

questions.question: What is the main theme of the story?
questions.answer: Compassion, sacrifice, and the true meaning of happiness and beauty.

questions.question: What is a fable?
questions.answer: A short story, typically with animals as characters, conveying a moral.

questions.question: What is an anecdote?
questions.answer: A short amusing or interesting story about a real incident or person.

questions.question: What is a fairytale?
questions.answer: A children's story about magical and imaginary beings and lands.

questions.question: What is a parable?
questions.answer: A simple story used to illustrate a moral or spiritual lesson.

questions.question: What is a tragedy?
questions.answer: A play or story dealing with tragic events and having an unhappy ending.

questions.question: What is a humorous story?
questions.answer: A story intended to amuse and provoke laughter.

questions.question: What is a detective story?
questions.answer: A story whose plot revolves around the investigation and solving of a crime.

questions.question: What is a myth?
questions.answer: A traditional story, especially one concerning the early history of a people or explaining a natural or social phenomenon.

questions.question: What are migratory birds?
questions.answer: Birds that fly from one part of the world to another in flocks seasonally.

questions.question: What is Direct Speech?
questions.answer: Reporting the exact words of the speaker within quotation marks.

questions.question: What is Indirect Speech?
questions.answer: Reporting the content of what the speaker said without using their exact words.

questions.question: What is an infinitive?
questions.answer: The basic form of a verb, usually preceded by 'to' (e.g., to go).

questions.question: What is a present participle?
questions.answer: A verb form ending in -ing that functions as an adjective (e.g., swimming pool).

questions.question: What is a past participle?
questions.answer: A verb form usually ending in -ed, -en, etc., that functions as an adjective (e.g., stolen jewels).

questions.question: What is a gerund?
questions.answer: A verb form ending in -ing that functions as a noun (e.g., Swimming is fun).

questions.question: What is a homophone?
questions.answer: Words that sound the same but have different spellings and meanings (e.g., write/right).

questions.question: What is a heteronym?
questions.answer: Words that have the same spelling but different pronunciations and meanings (e.g., read/read).

questions.question: What is a homograph?
questions.answer: Words that are spelled the same and may sound the same but have different meanings in different contexts (e.g., light).

questions.question: What was the Prince's palace called?
questions.answer: The Prince's palace was called Sans-Souci.

questions.question: What does the name 'Sans-Souci' mean?
questions.answer: It means 'without worry'.

questions.question: Why was the Prince called 'Happy' during his lifetime?
questions.answer: He lived a carefree life without knowing sorrow or suffering.

questions.question: What was the Swallow's original destination?
questions.answer: The Swallow was going to Egypt.

questions.question: Why did the Swallow decide to stay back in the city?
questions.answer: Because he felt pity for the Happy Prince and wanted to help him.

questions.question: Which season had already arrived when the Swallow was still in the city?
questions.answer: Winter had arrived.

questions.question: What did the Swallow notice about the people in the streets?
questions.answer: He noticed that the people were poor, hungry, and suffering.

questions.question: What did the Prince request the Swallow to do at night?
questions.answer: To fly over the city and report the sufferings of the people.

questions.question: Why did the children look pale and thin?
questions.answer: Because they were poor and did not have enough food.

questions.question: What was the condition of the seamstress' room?
questions.answer: It was cold, small, and poorly lit.

questions.question: Why did the Prince feel miserable after losing both eyes?
questions.answer: Because he became completely blind.

questions.question: What was the Prince's last request to the Swallow?
questions.answer: To stay with him always and be his companion.

questions.question: What made the Swallow weak and slow?
questions.answer: The cold weather and continuous acts of kindness.

questions.question: Why was the Swallow unable to fly anymore?
questions.answer: Because he had grown very weak due to cold.

questions.question: What was the colour of the Prince after all the gold was removed?
questions.answer: He became dull grey in colour.

questions.question: Why did people no longer admire the statue?
questions.answer: Because it had lost its beauty and jewels.

questions.question: What did the Mayor say about the statue?
questions.answer: He said it was ugly and useless.

questions.question: Why was the broken heart thrown away?
questions.answer: Because it could not be melted.

questions.question: Who chose the Swallow and the broken heart as precious?
questions.answer: God chose them as the most precious things.

questions.question: What place was promised to the Swallow?
questions.answer: A place in the garden of Paradise.

questions.question: Why was the Prince unhappy after becoming a statue?
questions.answer: Because he could see the misery of the people.

questions.question: What quality does the Prince show by giving away his gold?
questions.answer: He shows generosity and selflessness.

questions.question: Why did the Swallow admire the Prince?
questions.answer: Because of his kindness and love for the poor.

questions.question: Why did the Swallow feel proud to serve the Prince?
questions.answer: Because he was helping suffering people.

questions.question: What lesson does the statue teach the city?
questions.answer: That true beauty lies in kindness and sacrifice.

questions.question: What does the broken heart symbolize?
questions.answer: It symbolizes deep love and compassion.

questions.question: Why is the story considered a moral tale?
questions.answer: Because it teaches values of kindness and sacrifice.

questions.question: How does the Prince help the children in the city?
questions.answer: By giving away his gold to them.

questions.question: What made the Swallow stay till death?
questions.answer: His love and loyalty towards the Prince.

questions.question: What does the story say about real happiness?
questions.answer: Real happiness comes from helping others.

questions.question: Why did the Prince call the Swallow his friend?
questions.answer: Because the Swallow stayed with him and helped him.

questions.question: What did the Prince lose to help the poor?
questions.answer: He lost his gold, jewels, and eyes.

questions.question: Why was the Swallow happy despite the cold?
questions.answer: Because he was doing good deeds.

questions.question: How does the story end?
questions.answer: With the Prince and the Swallow being rewarded by God.

questions.question: What emotion dominates the story?
questions.answer: Compassion.

questions.question: Why did the Prince ask the Swallow to pluck off his gold?
questions.answer: To give it to the needy people.

questions.question: What kind of ruler was the Prince when alive?
questions.answer: A carefree ruler who did not know sorrow.

questions.question: Why is the Swallow called brave?
questions.answer: Because he sacrificed his life to help others.

questions.question: What makes the Prince a true hero?
questions.answer: His sacrifice for the happiness of others.

questions.question: What kind of life did the poor people lead?
questions.answer: They lived a life full of misery and hunger.

questions.question: Why was the statue no longer valued?
questions.answer: Because it had lost its jewels and shine.

questions.question: What quality of the Swallow is most touching?
questions.answer: His loyalty.

questions.question: What made the Prince’s heart break?
questions.answer: The death of the Swallow.

questions.question: Why is the story emotional?
questions.answer: Because it shows sacrifice and death for love.

questions.question: What makes the Swallow a noble character?
questions.answer: His readiness to sacrifice his life.

questions.question: Why did the Prince say he was no longer Happy?
questions.answer: Because he could see suffering all around.

questions.question: What does the story suggest about beauty?
questions.answer: True beauty lies in kindness, not appearance.

questions.question: Why did the Swallow ignore his own comfort?
questions.answer: To help the poor people of the city.

questions.question: What is the moral of the story?
questions.answer: Helping others brings true happiness.

questions.question: Why is 'The Happy Prince' a timeless story?
questions.answer: Because its message of love and sacrifice is always relevant.
